job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Portland, OR
pros: They assume new employees can do the same work as fast as someone who has been there for years and are very focused on little things instead of the bigger picture. So if you’re the kind of person who can adjust to basically being on “surveillance” by your manager, this may be a good fit for you. I have honestly never worked in a place that was like this before and if I had known prior, I would have stayed with my former hospital because who wants to work for a manager that is consistently looking for your wrongs? The expectations are extremely high despite how low the pay is compared to other Portland hospitals. The staffing ratios are good, which was one of the only things I liked about this place and drew me to want to work here but due to the fact that I was being singled out by a a micromanager who consistently scrutinized me for very small things that most other jobs would not take as seriously, it was not worth it for me to stay. I felt very uncomfortable and distrusted knowing my manager was trying to get me out for something that should have never been a big deal to begin with. Which for a lot of people, this is a very difficult way to work and it definitely does not foster reciprocal safe feeling work relationships. Please do yourself a favor and apply elsewhere if you want to be respected and paid better because this was by far the most toxic work environment I’ve been in and I’m very thankful to have left this organization.

job_title: Systems Engineer III in Portland, OR
pros:
-Flexible Schedule
-Decent Base Salary
-Friendly and Understanding Management (Mostly)
-Talented Co-Workers
-Supportive of Remote Work
cons:
-Very difficult to advance your career. There are few opportunities available.
-If you do manage to advance to the next level of your career track the accompanying pay raise is typically disappointing. Usually a nominal 5-10%.
-Yearly COL raises are pitifully low. They average 1.5% of the median of your pay range. So you're looking at a 0.75% yearly COL in a time when inflation is hitting a 6% increase each year.
-All of these drawbacks taken together create an environment where "going above and beyond" is significantly disincentivized. And many people are simply keeping the lights on and collecting a paycheck.
-The C suite executives have an extremely flat heirarchy which allows for far too much swirl in regards to decision making as well as a culture of finger pointing and "passing the buck" to a different executive/branch of the organization.

job_title: Internal Medicine Resident in Portland, OR
pros:
Truly an excellent residency program that is based out of 2 major hospitals ~7min away from each other in the downtown area. The program is more focused on inpatient than outpatient medicine, but the outpatient experience is still great. Considering the ICU is open, this provides a greater focus on ICU medicine than other Internal Medicine Residencies. This provides considerable comfort with ICU medicine even within the 2nd year of residency. There is a significant amount of autonomy on nights, but full support from intensivists and hospitalists is always a call/text/page away. Most impressive aspect of the program are the attendings, whether hospitalists, intensivists, outpatient, or specialty rotations, it is clear that Legacy has made an effort to craft a highly supportive, academic, and non-intimidating envirnment. I am currently an R3, and every year the program makes great strides to decrease burnout and ensure a healthy work-life balance. Residents with less experience, less knowledge, or struggling compared to their cohort are not reprimanded or made to feel small but rather given extra attention and scheduling modifications to catch them up. This is the furthest thing from a malignant program. 10/10 would recommend this program to any prospective IM residents.
The core faculty, support staff, leadership & benefits package are all outstanding.
cons: Outpatient experience can be challenging as the patient population is underserved and tend to have concomitant addiction, behavioral health & compliance issues.

review_title: Best choice I made was to join Legacy Health
pros: There are several positive aspects joining LH. One, the team atmosphere is a strong component of the culture. Each member is a source of information and willing to knowledge-share. Another great characteristic is the work-life balance. Coming from an industry that considers 24/7 access the norm, the balance here at LH has been a breath of fresh air, and I am thankful for it!  The benefits are excellent for employees and their families.
cons:
I have not experienced too many negatives as of yet. One has been the ability to adopt new technologies. This is a slow process. However, I have noticed some quicker, more agile areas where the culture's agility is increasing. 
Another negative is that certain employment entry levels have low salary ranges. The inflexibility regarding salary is a disadvantage against most other industry/market segments.  With the flatness of the organization, the opportunity to 'move-up' via title/level to gain the next salary step, are far and few between.  This was the one area that made me hesitant to join. If there is a timeliness to salary improvements for these individuals, that will keep attrition lower.

pros: Great coworkers, which make it worth while staying
cons: Institution and management doesn’t value staff nor staff safety

pros: I've worked for 3 different health systems in the Portland Metro area over the 25 years I've been in healthcare. Legacy is unique in that the overall culture is positive, and for the most part, staff seem happy. If you have an idea that may improve costs, or patient care, management has been very supportive of seeing that you get the resources you need and/ or studies done to make it happen. They are also supportive, and encouraging continuing or advancing your education. All in all, a great place to work.
cons: While it's probably not unique to just Legacy- but all health systems- the process of getting an interview is way too slow. After you apply for an open position on their website, you receive an email stating someone will get back to you in the next 1-2 weeks. I applied for the same open positions across 3 of the hospitals in the system, and didn't get a call from HR for about 7 weeks. I was also rejected via email for one of the 3 positions for "not being qualified", when I was actually interviewed and hired for the exact same position at another facility. Unless you're already working there, or know someone on the "inside", you can't follow up after submitting your CV.

job_title: Speech Language Pathologist in Rolesville, NC

pros:
Above-average industry wages 
Excellent health benefits 
Generous time-off
cons:
When you go to the new hire on-boarding you're told how great the organization is; tons of room for career growth they say. The reality is unless you've got an "in" with the hiring manager in the department you're looking to transfer into or you get exceptionally lucky your room for growth is extremely limited. I joined Legacy because I wanted to work in a healthcare environment and put my education and experience to good use. 

Even with nearly a decade of experience in my field & a graduate school degree I'm still working in a position that requires only a high school diploma. I've reached out to department managers who had open positions and have never once had a response back. When I try calling that goes no where either. I've heard the same story from MANY fellow employees that I've spoken with across multiple departments. It all comes down to who you know. 

It's unfortunate that the career growth potentials are so limited; I took a step down in pay because I believed in the image that the company portrayed and hoped to move up internally. I have an excellent manager, honestly the best manager I've ever had but I'm at the top of my payscale and can no longer progress in the organization. I'm already actively applying elsewhere but hope something pans out before I leave the organization entirely.

review_title: Still glad to have moved across the country to work for Legacy
pros: I absolutely love my job, and it's not a position that's available at a lot of hospitals nationwide. I am well-respected in my department and feel like I hit the lottery regarding my manager. Good Samaritan in particular has a very relaxed but professional, family-like culture. Coming from the for-profit end of healthcare, I appreciate Legacy's values as a NFP and especially as compared to Catholic hospitals in the area whose service offerings are limited by their non-evidence based beliefs, and who are notably absent from community events such as the yearly Pride parade. Benefits are excellent, at least compared to for-profit clinics, which are my background.
cons: Big hospital systems come with lots of red tape and delays in getting things accomplished. I've had some information systems requests take as long as 14 months to get completed. Having a manager who's willing to go to bat for you helps though.

review_title: Legacy is filled with some truly wonderful professionals, but it is struggling for footing in today's health care world.
pros: Legacy Health has a laudable mission, many dedicated and highly skilled professionals, and a desire to do the right thing in the community. Amazing work happens within the hospital walls every day. The quality of medical care and human caring is high.
cons: Something is off balance about the system's culture. Perhaps it is the result of trying to knit together six hospitals that, in some senses, compete against each other for limited resources. Yet all the hospitals and system office staff are supposed to work together as one unified family. The organization has not yet found a way to make it work. The culture and leadership can be excellent at the hospital level, however, so your job satisfaction can really depend on the site you work.

pros: The benefits are excellent, with low copays, zero deductible, very good prescription coverage, dental, flexible spending account, vision, several hundred dollars of "alternative medicine" coverage, and of course, a network of providers and pharmacies within the System to patronize. The majority of employees are caring and friendly and are doing their part to ensure patients continue to remain priority #1.
cons: The facilities are dreary, except in areas patients and other customers are expected. This means anyplace the employees are going to be, the desks, walls, carpets and office machines might just be older than they are. The Values and Mission, like many companies, are apparently only for the purpose of hanging in a frame or posting on the website. They're definitely not carried throughout the organization.The company doesn't value its employees and it's apparent from the demoralization which is palpable from the rank and file.

pros: The Children's hospital is aesthetically pleasing. People smile when they see you. There are some staff that are not passive aggressive and really want to make it a better place to work
cons: They are disingenuous when they say patient care comes first. It is a businesses, and the bottom line is always first. They have a habit of squeezing what they can from employees. Brilliant employees are fired because they advocate for change. Employee concerns are marginalized. Employees are not valued if they do not nod and smile.  They view part time as a weakness and outwardly will voice that leaders can not work part time. The head of the children's hospital often says, "I had two nannies, and expect you to do the same." This is regardless of your status.They are known to have a high physician turn over rate, which is because when physicians see the "inside" they are fired so the organization can protect themselves.

review_title: Avoid Legacy Hospice at all costs!
job_title: Clinical Social Worker in Portland, OR
pros: Non-management level staff try to support one another in lieu of receiving support from management.  Field staff seem to genuinely care about their patients and work hard to support them despite manufactured barriers created by management.
cons: The worst management imaginable. There is a particular RN clinic supervisor that actively works against good employees. Micromanaging employees who work remotely amounts to creating problems that are not there and ends up doubling the day to day work. Employees are penalized for the failures of management — when census drops low, you can expect that you’ll be sent home without pay and without choice in the matter. Patients suffer as a result and management does nothing to support field staff or patients.

The staff is incredibly lazy. No one is willing to work. They just want to come in, spend time, get paid for just showing up their faces. KEEP DOING THIS FOR YEARS AND GET INCREMENTS. 
Salaries and bonuses are not performance based. Rather years worked at Legacy based.  So no need to do any hard work just stick around and sit around and get paid.
They should have signs up at main entrance saying ' Heavenly abode for Lazy people. Come and sit on your behinds forever.'
WORK HERE IF YOU LOVE TO GOSSIP. Gossip and chatter is all employees do. I dont blame them. They have to do something while sitting around or it will get boring. Its not like their salaries depend on any performances or targets. 
The Departments work in silos with hardly any teamwork towards achieving any company initiatives. 
Lack lustre work environment. If you want to work and learn and achieve something at work, go find another company.

review_title: Oncology services not standard of care
pros: Everyone is nice at Legacy facilities. There seems to be good comradery between physicians and staff, with a less formal feeling than at other institutions in the area.
cons: The pay is low for the area. The executive management doesn't make good decisions. They lose their best doctors as a result. Some of the doctors they promote in their media don't practice standard of care. This makes it difficult to take their medical care seriously.

pros: Stable work environment and flexible schedule. 401k match.
cons: Be sure to negotiate your salary up front or you will get stuck creeping along at a dismal 3% for the rest of your time in the job classification. Compensation is not merit based, so you have to be self-motivated.Due to budget cuts a few years back, they expect a lot out of each employee- so be ready to bring your A game  all day every day. Tried to get re-classed as my workload and responsibilities changed significantly and does not reflect the job title, but was told no.

pros: I work with a great group of people every day. The nurses and other staff I communicate with on a daily basis are always happy and friendly to me. I have been a nurse here for less than six months but feel very welcomed and supported by the team. Management seems truly committed to the success of employees and great patient outcomes.
cons: I truly have a tough time thinking of cons for working here. The worst thing I deal with would be the traffic but that obviously has nothing to do with legacy. I work at the Emanuel campus and it is an older building and sometimes difficult for some patients to navigate. The rooms in the department I work in are small also.

pros: Great position to elevate your skills as an advanced laboratory personnel. Work shifts are early morning, swing and overnight shifts. Competitive wages with differential pay for swing and overnight shifts.
cons: Management needs to be more active with handling employee concerns regarding work related procedures that could impact the integrity of a specimen. GREAT Employee satisfaction is not that great because communication within the department is diluted between management. Employee promotion and/or movement for growth is nonexistent unless you have a BS degree or higher.

review_title: Legacy has lost it's secondary customer focus - employees
pros: Legacy  works hard to be the best Health Care System in the region.
cons: it's getting too big for it's own good.  In it's growth, there has been a disconnect between management and employees: the front lines and the bottom lines.  It really tries to do and be the best - which is great - but the sheer size of the system makes it so difficult for communication to work personally as well as professionally.  I feel that there is an unspoken notion that one is not to get to know their managers, nor is there time granted to deal with teamwork or personnel issues.

pros: Excellent doctors..dedicated wonderful doctors!  Great coworkers.  I worked with some amazing staff there.
cons: Terrible low level management.  Benefits are marginal.  Low level managers ride roughshod over employees without any redress.  You will not be heard at this company.  You will be worked until you can be replaced by a newer cheaper model. I would not recommend this employer unless you are looking short term for some skills training.  There are much better places to work where you will be treated with respect.

pros:
Opportunities to work with some truly Amazing people.  Absolute room for growth if you know the right people to speak to and are an effective brown noser.

the surrounding area around the Lovejoy campus is truly remarkable, could spend a career wandering around Portland's northwest finding things to do after work.
cons:
For a healthcare company they sure provide shotty benefits at best.  MODA the primary insurance provider will not cover any outside specialists or services, the dental is a joke too.

Sick days = your accrued Vacation time. 5 holidays off a year..

Do not expect a work/life balance once employed in the system office.
For Epic analysts, recommend seriously weighing other options before joining the team.
The inner office politics can turn toxic pretty quick.

review_title: Very Difficult to Move Up in this company
pros: Hard to say anything positive when there is no recognition or incentive or room to grow no matter your performance.
cons: Nothing is based on performance and everyone is paid a 3% annual increase. There is no reward system and people only care about the weekend. People live by the clock and when they will go home. Very little encouragement from managers and pay is low so employees don't try to care about each other. People complain about the littlest things to their office managers about each other, and this is more of a child's school than a pro career environment. People have no motivation and are burnt out, patient care has gone down and cost have gone up as well as physician bonuses. Everyone in management thinks a pizza day will make up how employees really feel.

pros: Excellent company to work for the past 26 years and counting.  Good pay and benefits package, forward-thinking management, excellent community-minded presence, and many top-notch doctors and nursing staff.  I'm proud of the work we do here and believe we are doing excellent work.
cons:
Working in a small but critical department, it is at times difficult to arrange for vacation time.
As a result, I have accrued many hours of paid time off, and would like to cash out some of the hours, but am unable to due to new policies.  (Some of which are governmental, not Legacy's.)

pros: Great benefits, great ideals, great treatment of the underserved community.  I adore their views on the underserved and how they commit to helping them.  True plus!!!
cons: Competing priorities creates a bi-polar and disorganized work culture.  Employees are important and valued in their stated "mission and values"; but the actualization is not there because of their competing values of being the frontrunner in medicine coupled with their participation in most of the new govt programs are not compatible,  The new regulations do not take employee/provider satisfaction into account and the new programs require more staff then Legacy will commit too.  They will fail if they haven't adjusted this crucial piece...

review_title: Best Little Big Place to Work
pros: I've worked in military medicine, private practices and corporate.  Legacy takes all the good things from these 3 distinctly different work environments and blends them together wonderfully.  There is a great deal of transparency and collaboration.  Our mission statement has our people first - and this organization DOES take care of its people.  We practice in a Just Culture, so we're tough on process but soft on people, allowing us (as an organization) to actually find broken processes and fix them for the system for greater safety!
cons: Well, it is a larger organization - so sometimes change takes a little longer than we'd like.

review_title: Don't Waste Your Career at this Organization
pros: Health benefits are ok at best
cons: Visionless leadership, clueless VPs/Directors/Management, no career growth, and years behind other companies. Most of the frontline managers in the Information Services department have little current or relevant technical experience and come from project management or non-technical backgrounds where pushing paper is more highly valued than leading, mentoring, and building efficient and high performing technology teams. If you are looking for a job with little to no expectations, no career growth, no training, opportunities, or recognition then join this company.

job_title: Safety and Security Officer in Portland, OR
pros: They pay you... You get lots of vacation time
cons: Medical, dental, and vision cost you a lot of you have a family. You make complaints about their illegal practices and HIPAA violations, they will fire you!! Retirement account seems to always lose money. They seem to fire over 300 employees every year so upper management gets more money in their pockets, management doesn’t care about you (they will remind you that you’re easily replaceable), staff treats patients horribly. They don’t supply paper cups, plates, silverware in your break rooms in order to save themselves money, new ceo is HORRIBLE!!!! And the list goes on.

job_title: Direct Patient Care in Portland, OR
pros: Salary was good and great people to work with - I loved all my teams.  My immediate supervisor was great. Benefit package was good some years ago but has been chipped away over the years, leaving it less than impressive and less than Legacy's competitors.
cons: Every year, Legacy surveys its employees and every year we said we did not feel heard or supported by Administration.  This was never acknowledged, much less addressed.  The work is challenging, never boring, but there is no recognition or support from upper management for departmental or individual contribution.

review_title: It's a job.  Salary is competitive, work is interesting, but not a place for professional growth.
pros: Good work/life balance, interesting projects, friendly work atmosphere.  Legacy really does care about the community and provides more than it's share of uninsured/charity care.
cons: Support for career development is non-existent.  Little opportunity for advancement. Training of IT personnel and users of the system is done at initial implementation, but little if any training in subsequent years or after system upgrades.

pros: pay is adequate, but not great.
cons:
Therapists are hourly and they make you "flex" when you don't have a patient. So there are hours you are sitting around not getting paid because they didn't fill your schedule for you or a patient cancelled. 

Benefits are not good. There is no continuing education. There are no paid holidays or sick time. There is only accrued time off and it accrues on 5 year schedules. It is around 2 weeks the first 5 years, then 3 weeks for years 6-10 then 4 for years 10 on. 

There is no continuing education money. You may luck out and get a "free" spot when they host a course, but you have to work it.  They pool the con ed funds with nursing, and nursing being a much bigger department gets most of the funds. One or two therapists will get one weekend course every year.  In Washington you need 24 hours to renew your license.  

They have an outside agency that manages work comp and medical leave. Their role seems to be to deny or try not to pay you. Even if you buy the extra disability insurance, they find ways not to pay any benefits. They pay short and long term disability once a month. The first payment is after you have already been off for at least 7 weeks depending on the pay periods, it could be 9 weeks. Then you get your check to find they have found a loophole and you aren't going to get any benefits. 

They recently laid off a lot of clinical staff, then created new upper management positions. 

The new CEO is focused only on money. She isn't a physician and has no medical background. Her main focus is cutting costs so that she and upper management can enjoy salary increases and bonuses.

review_title: Uneven Leadership Maintains Organizational Norms that are Unsustainable in an Era of Healthcare Transformation
pros:
1.) George Brown is a great leader, probably the best among the major systems in our region. 
2.) As an employee, you can be proud of the quality of care provided at Legacy sites, which is as high or higher than the other systems in our region. 
3.) More than the other healthcare systems, Legacy promotes an ethos of "doing the right thing" and does as good a job as any large organization can do to abide by it. Their commitment to diversity is exemplified in many ways, most notably through the presence of an African American man in the CEO position. There is also a strong commitment to healthcare literacy.
4.) Pay, at least for certain classes of administrative functions, is highly competitive. (but see "con" #4, below)
5.) Legacy is the largest provider of unreimbursed care in our region--evidence of a genuine commitment to the underserved. Hence, they deserve the classification of "non-profit" that many other health systems in our country don't.
cons:
1.)  Weak links among the senior and executive leadership teams, and too much internal bickering within their ranks.
2. ) Initially, the presence of so many longterm employees at Legacy may seem a good sign--however, it is both a cause of inertia and an outcome of tolerance for mediocrity. 
3.) When faced with organizational issues, Legacy too often takes a "try to make everybody happy" approach, rather than making smart business decisions.
4.) Poor HR policies that, again, strive to be "fair," rather than rewarding excellence. So Instead of "pay for performance, Legacy claims to extend "the same" percentage pay raise to all employees, except this is not true: everybody gets the same percentage raise, based on the midpoint of their position''s pay range. This means if you were hired near the top of your pay range (due to good qualifications), you actually receive a lesser raise than those whose pay is at the lower end. Frustration with lack of reward leads to Legacy losing talented employees while retaining mediocre ones.
5. ) Benefits not on par with other health systems. Most notably, there is no paid holiday. Instead, holidays are deducted from employees' bank of earned vacation days.

Transparent Leadership Communication - Healthcare is constantly changing, I felt the leadership communicated any organization changes coming in a transparent manner.  CEO communications felt very genuine and inspiring.
Great mission, your work supports something that really makes a difference in lives
cons:
Many analysts have clinical experience, but no technical background
Low cube walls, desktops vs. laptops, small monitors
No casual Friday's
Lack of direct technical experience in IT management
Required to be on after hours call rotation

cons: Pharmacy department in all sites does not get enough recognition for their services and initiatives. It would be great if all staff knew that pharmacy week is in October and would acknowledge our services as we do with RNs and MDs, etc. Apart from that, not many cons.

Flexibility was great here. Amazing coworkers. Great culture.
